title: Using Big Data for International Development

author: Alex Rutherford, Global Pulse, United Nations

segmentation: Next up, we have Alex Rutherford from the United Nations Global Pulse and for the sake of time I'll just let him take it away.
Please welcome Alex.
Hi good evening everyone wow.
Feel like a Rockstar even more than normal.
OK so thanks everyone for organizing this.
This has been a really amazing and inspiring few days so I work at United Nations Global Pulse.
I imagine most of you have heard of the United Nations.
Right OK, good I.
But you may not have heard of Global Pulse, and in a nutshell, global pulse is the data science unit.
That's the wrong site.
That's the right slide.
The global pulse is the data science unit of the UN.
What that means is UN agencies like World Health Organization will food program.
They come to us, and they say we have a data gap.
We have an information gap.
We want better data so we can make better decisions and we help them to do that.
We tell them about data science.
We tell them about Big data machine learning, all that cool stuff.
So these are people who are working on really hard, really important problems.
Public health, urban resilience, disaster response, and they're doing it in really challenging places.
So this is this is a hard problem and we realized that we cannot do this by ourselves.
So part of our role as global Pulse is to be kind of a bridge iHub between all of these people.
All of these different actors.
So we have UN organizations.
We have academics who are doing cool new stuff in the literature.
We have private companies who have data and tools that we want to make use of as well as local governments and so on.
So we sit in the middle and try and find solutions.
And what do we mean when we talk about a data gap or an information gap?
So really nice example is migration, so migration is something that lots of people across the spectrum want to know about.
How many people are coming into a country?
How many people are leaving?
Where are they going to?
Why they leaving?
So this is something that you know we can use normal data sources to solve.
So I had to make a confession at this point.

I am a masochist an I'm a masochist because I've moved between 5 different countries since 2008 and one thing I can tell you with that experience is you do an awful lot of Googling before you move country.
Where am I going to live?
How do I get an apartment?
How do I get a bank account?
All that good stuff.
So we use that hypothesis.
We said, well, maybe we can use Google searches and maybe we can use that as a proxy for people moving.
And yes you can.
So what you're looking at here is.
Actual migration data.
This is people moving from Italy to Australia and you're also seeing the time series of how they search for work in Australia.
And it works pretty nicely, right?
And this is, this really exemplifies all the things we want to do.
This is a proxy for for normal official statistics.
These official statistics are to use official UN terminology a bit crappy.
You have one number.
It comes out annually, quarterly.
If you're lucky, no one knows where it comes from.
Maybe it's not even available at all, so this is a way to kind of get some sort of noisy picture in a simple, straightforward kind of way.
This is open Google search, Bing search, DuckDuckGo search data.
OK.
So you know, working for you when it's amazing.
I it's my dream job and one of the things that really gets me out of bed in the morning.
Apart from the fact that I get to meet Bankey Moon an I have like a really cool blue badge, I get to make graphs like this or 192 by 192 global correlation matrix.
That's what really gets me out of bed in the morning.
So what you're looking at here?
This is how people search for job opportunities in each country.
And how does that match of people in each country looking at the same time in the same way?
Well, more or less, yes.
They are.
Like if you look along the diagonal you see these big red squares.
So everyone in the Middle East searches for job opportunities in the same way and in Europe they do the same thing.
But something funky happens in South America.
So if you look down here in Ecuador and Peru, these countries don't behave in the same way as the rest of the world or the rest of South America.
But they do behave in the same way as each other.
So in some sense that there's something weird going on here, they coupled that you know the economy.
People looking for job opportunities, people interested in job opportunities.
It's behaving completely differently.
I can tell you now with complete confidence that I do not understand why this is happening.
But it's interesting to dig in and figure it out.
What's also nice about this is this is something completely different to normal official statistics.
This isn't the same as unemployment statistics.
This is people who are maybe unemployed, but maybe they are employed and they want a better job.
So this is a really fun new innovative way of looking at the world.
So one of the things that we think about a lot.
A global pulses data privacy and for sure it's the elephant in the room.
It's one of the biggest debates that we're really having in the 21st century.
So we want to find a way to.
But to figure that figure out this this problem right, you have you have personal data and everyone has a right to privacy.
But there's going to be some situations where this personal data could be shared, and it could help people get their right to shelter to food and water and so on.
So we're looking actively at.

New modalities, new ways to share data that satisfies both of these constraints and one example is some work that we did in the Tabasco region of Mexico, and we found that you don't need personal peoples personal individualized phone traces.
All you need is the volume through the towers and you can see where people are, where they're displaced and you can get to them and you can help them.
And I will finish up just by talking about another project that we're doing.
Investigating peoples people around the world looking at everyone's interest, their needs, and contributing to the Post 2015 development agenda.
This is the development priorities which will replace the Millennium Development Goals.
We've built out a 25,000 word taxonomy in five different languages.
So if you want to help if you want to be part of this, if you speak Urdu, Swahili, Arabic, all of these awesome languages and you want to be a part of this, you can help us translate it.
Thanks very much.
